title: Would different age groups in solo queue be viable?
body:
**NEW TITLE**: 
**Would making a separate solo-queue for well-behaved players do any good for us on the problem of toxicity?**


Just thinking about how it might be viable to introduce an age-appropriate solo queue.
Personally feel as if there's a bit of a problem with different age groups being matched into games with one another, it just leaves a lot of room for conflict in most cases. Originally,  I made this post specifically towards age .. but through discussing I figured the problem had more to do with maturity rather.. which varies throughout age-groups. I personally don't enjoy playing games with people who haven't " grown up ", it honestly just puts me off the game for a couple of reasons - having to deal with constant nagging, ragers, abusers.. it's a little ridiculous. I feel as if queues need to be made for like-minded people - specifically: independent queues for people who are toxic, and another for people who are well-behaved.

The reason why such a proposition is so important is because as a community, we really don't get much of an option with what kind of people we get to deal with in solo queue. I feel as if regardless of how much we enforce our leaver buster, how much we enforce our reporting/muting systems - we won't be able to rid ourselves of trolls. This is because we literally only have one platform for ranked solo-queue.

I think that what I was trying to aim for with the whole age reference was that there are obvious issues in having adults playing ranked with young teens, specifically the differences in attitude. I can see age as being a primary factor in determining eligibility if such a queue were to exist, but not necessarily being the only determinant. Ultimately, it would have to be the personals overall behaviour that would determine whether a person would be eligible to join or not.

What i'm asking for here is an alternative queue that will promote behavioural changes in the community. More incentive to be positive throughout games. All of our current incentive systems , like border ribbons .. and... is there really anything else? they don't really bring much substance to the community imo. I feel as if this could be somewhat valuable to solving the whole issue of toxicity in our community.

Note:
For those who read this post before 100 views, you'll notice that I completely rewrote the opening segment.
I felt like It was poorly written, and didn't really express the idea as it was intended.

Anyways, thoughts on this  would be much appreciated.
Let's get a discussion going.

replies.body:
> [{quoted}](name=Lnar,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=PsQtVy9I,comment-id=,timestamp=2014-12-22T05:09:40.912+0000)
>
> Then you've also got the immaturity with some of the younger players that us older players are kinda getting a bit sick of.

And you get that same immaturity with any age group. Age doesn't determine a persons maturity.

> I think this kind of says a little about the **difference in attitude between the younger players and the more mature players** in the community.

What difference? There is no difference.

Not considering the fact that there are just as many immature idiots in this game above 18, what's to stop people from lying about their age? Tell people they can't do something and what's the first thing they do? This suggestion is flawed both because there is no age limit to immaturity and people would just lie about their age to get into 18+ queue.

Sorry for the late response, I've just come back from work.
Now, you're making a reasonable assumption in saying that there are just as many immature idiots in this game that are over the age of 18, so, I won't argue against that. To tell me that my suggestion is flawed, well, I see a problem in your assumption.

You want to tell me that people would be able to lie about their age in order to get into an 18+ queue, well, you're right, they can.
But lying doesn't necessarily change a persons attitude, does it?
I would expect that if such a queue were implemented, it would not be taken for granted. Certain measures would be carried out to keep "what was promised", that being : a queue that is intended for a certain level of behaviour.

Now, in saying that, we need to consider what it is that constitutes mature behaviour, we could assume a variety of factors but to keep things short, we'll just go along the lines of " people who aren't toxic" . I would expect that if such a queue was administered into the game, a tribunal of sorts would be responsible in keeping order via. in game reports. LeaverBusters or automated punishments systems would be a liability for the community, as there is always a possibility that someone may be falsely reported for something that didn't happen, which is why an independent tribunal would be key in maintaining the peace.


Now, considering the possibility that those who are interested in joining the queue but do not belong there for obvious reasons, may try and make an account with false information. Let me remind you that for those who play ranked, accounts need to hit level 30 to be eligible. That grind takes a couple of days, and it is very unlikely that there would be people who would re-create accounts to have a couple of games in said queue simply to troll ( which would be a whole other level of trolling ).
If we consider that people are at risk of losing eligibility due to certain flaws in their own behaviour, then, we would have a queue that promotes incentive to be nicer to others.

Back to your point about how age doesn't play a significant role in the behaviour of our players in this community, I would like to say that I agree with you, but, to a certain extent only. It is true that there are some older people in this community that are immature, have bad social-awarenesses, and are overall toxic to the community, but I'm gonna have to say that it is more prominent among the younger players. Having said that, there are plenty of younger players that show a good attitude when playing with others, and they're welcome to partake in said queue. 

What it comes down to, at the end of the day, is that "good" players deserve to play among better communities of people.
It is impossible to achieve this when you have everyone playing in one queue.
Every community in league deserves to be paired with their own " age - appropriate, or better said, behaviour appropriate " players.
Let us pair toxic players with toxic players, and reasonable players with reasonable players.

So basically what you are saying is, their needs to be a queue where 0 toxicity is tolerable? or you get permabanned? 
Sounds pretty fair, it would remove a lot of the toxicity in the game. 
Except idk if riot would do anything about swearing in codes, like "STFU and SMD"

Yeah :)
I'm not too sure about being perma-banned, it's really hard to come up with an entire solution to this whole thing without having spent a significant amount of time contemplating over it.
I think words like STFU or SMD are pretty harmless, it all depends on context honestly. It seems like in-game abuse is more of a problem that needs to be dealt with, and having this alternative would definitely promote better behaviour in some cases.

Lets face facts here, what you're talking about is a Utopian community where there's no toxicity or trolling yet that's what Riot (or rather any community "government") has been trying to achieve all the time. Adding in more types of 'queues' wont change the facts, people will be toxic and some will sneak past the punishment systems. You say that people will not grind to level 30 just to troll and that's true (for the vast majority anyway), however you failed to consider that these individuals have ready access to accounts that are already level 30, whether it be by purchase, trade or sharing. Your entire suggestion will change nothing about the way this game works, there will still be the same level of toxicity and trolling it will just be spread across more 'queues'.

I feel like you're disagreeing just for the sake of disagreeing.
Sure, we could look at it as some sort of a Utopian idea, a sectioned off safe-zone for those that are well-behaved.
Your pessimism is clear, and I feel like you're being somewhat ignorant of the points that have been made throughout this post.
To imply that such an implementation would not change OCE for the better is somewhat of an ungrounded refutation of the matter.

Your claim that individuals will have ready access to accounts is somewhat valid, but fails to work consistently with the aforementioned point that : the system won't be taken for granted. certain prerequisites would be necessary to participate in the queue. Those who go against TOU would find themselves ineligible to participate, unless circumstances allow otherwise.

Trolling/'toxicity seems to be a behavior associated with a poor-development in the human psyche.
This development varies from age groups via. different factors. One of the main factors I've mentioned in this post would be child-development (( children/teens ) are still developing, hence, immature behavior is prevalent in most cases )
There are a fair number of players in OCE who are well-behaved, yet still have to deal with those who are not. 
To not be given an alternative is much like being forced into a corner with people you don't want to be around.
People play this game as a form of entertainment, but certain people in the community disregard the well-being of others and as a result, create somewhat of a detrimental experience.
Having said that, There is ALOT going for this idea of a sectioned off queue specified for those who are well behaved, because, let's face it, people are getting pretty sick of playing with assholes.
 I would appreciate that if you were to respond with anything dismissive of my suggestion, that you use a refutation that is well-grounded instead of assumptive.

> [{quoted}](name=Lnar,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=PsQtVy9I,comment-id=000100000000000000000000,timestamp=2014-12-22T13:08:35.915+0000)
>
> Your claim that individuals will have ready access to accounts is somewhat valid, but fails to work consistently with the aforementioned point that : **the system won't be taken for granted. **

It will be. People will find ways to abuse the system and, considering what you're suggesting, it wont be that hard for people to get level 30 accounts that are 'eligible' for the queue. Ultimately this would change nothing about how the game works and how people interact within it.

> Having said that, There is ALOT going for this idea of a sectioned off queue specified for those who are well behaved, because, let's face it, **people are getting pretty sick of playing with assholes.**

Then perhaps it's time those people play single player games, it's not like they're going to be able to play in peace if they choose to play F2P MMOs. There exists no online multiplayer game where people aren't force to play with assholes, if you think this suggestion will change that for LoL then I doubt you've really thought it through considering the general attitude of people over the internet.

just going to respond through the points that you made.

1. You're telling me that it won't be hard for people to get level 30 accounts. You realise that it takes a couple of days to hit 30, and for what, to get banned from  a couple of games? What incentive is there, honestly, it's simply irrational to assume that this is a behavior that will be norm'd as a consequence.

2. Why would you even suggest that, it is completely irrelevant to this discussion. Again, completely dismissive and deconstructive of what we're trying to discuss. You are following narrow-minded opinion rather than a well-thought observation. I asked that if you were to refute, to use well-grounded information.

EDIT: 

3. You can't compare league to other F2P MMO's. 
League is different in the sense that your own progression heavily relies on the others that are in your team.
It's not a matter of picking and choosing in soloqueue, you get what you're given.
Since we're on the topic of mmo's, let's look at WoW.
They have different servers for different sorts of people : Some are into RP, some are into Global PVP - These "allocated" servers are implemented for a reason : like minded people to be around one another.
Apply this to one of the main issues in LoL, *behavior* , then you'll see a sudden positive shift in the community.
Toxic players can thrive in a toxic environment, and those well-behaved can thrive in a cleaner more positive environment.

> [{quoted}](name=Lnar,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=PsQtVy9I,comment-id=00010000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2014-12-22T13:56:15.171+0000)
> 
> You're telling me that it won't be hard for people to get level 30 accounts. You realise that it takes a couple of days to hit 30, and for what, to get banned from the after a couple of games? What incentive is there, honestly, it's simply idiotic to assume that this is a behavior that will be adapted as a consequence.

That behaviour already exists, it will just adapt to the new system. Clearly you have not thought this through too well considering you didn't consider behaviour that already exists and claimed it simply wouldn't happen. You put too much faith in people not abusing things.

Too much faith? What kind of rationality implies that someone will devote 2-3 days making a new account in order to troll a specific queue? I'm not denying the fact that through initial phases this feature will be abused, but in turn, people will be kicked out. The same can't be said for our current ranked queue, there is only one ranked queue.  The whole idea is that at a certain point in time, most accounts that are currently in use will most likely be appropriated to their own queues. 

Again, it is unreasonable and improbable to assume that anyone would seriously devote 2-3 days to make troll-smurfs. The idea is just so counter-productive and does not serve anyone apart from those who seriously have nothing better to do, ( which is something that is really, really messed up to even consider in the first place ( these people need help) ) .

Also, refrain from the derogatory. Telling me that I **Clearly haven't thought something out too well** is rude, especially when I've invested a fair amount of time into this thread. Instead, take the right approach, if whatever you say has credibility to it - try a, "oh, well what about? I think you missed this.. ". Don't force your pessimistic bias into the conversation.
If whatever you have has substance to it, then we'll discuss on it. But the way I see it right now, you are dismissing for the sake of dismissing, you are the one failing to *think* about it.
You act as if people who reach x age are more mature than a person of a lesser age.

I can understand why you would see it that way, but i'd like to reassure you that my suggestion doesn't necessarily work that way.
It has more to do with behaviour, rather than age. The point i'm trying to make is that younger people have a tendency to behave ill-mannered than a clear-majority of adults. Sure, you have older people who will act like children, but that's just to say that they haven't exactly grown up yet.
And yes, you have younger players that may grow up earlier than some.
children, teenagers, and adults all misbehave, it's only that each age group do different inappropriate things.

Hmm. I can see what you're saying, and I guess you have something of a point to it.

But, children do tend to be a little harder to reason with, whereas you can talk to an adult and make your point, most of the time..
This is why I think few (children/teenagers) will participate in said queue, mainly because of the behavioural tendencies involved with those  ages.
the cause of that is a lack of discipline, it is a thing a lot of parents struggle with. and said parents can go f**u**ck themselves with a shovel

How about they just have a chat disabled queue and maybe even cover up everyone's names.

Hence making it a REAL solo queue.

interesting idea :p sort of like an incognito mode.
I think it might hinder communication a little, not that many people devote enough time to talk tactics in game. You do get a lot of people relying on pings for communication, the four different types seem to work very effectively. But yeah, I still think it's pretty important to be able to talk to your team.

It really helps muting everyone and covering up names (forgot the hotkey to do so). Feels like you're playing with bots; zero anxiety. Pings IMO cover up 3/4th of the communication issue. The only time when communication truly matters is in champion select I think.
Lol. %%%% off idiot.

The biggest problem with this is that in solo queue you get matched with players of your skill level, not age. If you categorize players into different age groups in solo queue, you would be waiting in queue a lot longer than usual, especially if you are very young or much older than the average player. Also, maturity can simply not be measured by age; a whole room full of 12 year olds will not create a better environment for gamers, it will just create even more animosity within the community. 

I can see that your overall point from this discussion is that you want a 'rage-free environment' when playing League of Legends, however I don't agree that the way to do that is to limit players into age restricted queues; I think it is simply a problem that Riot has to deal with by banning toxic players.

Yeah, you've got a really important point here - Something I feel like I don't have the exact answer to at the moment, but, I'll try to respond.
In saying that, age-division wouldn't necessarily work in a literal sense - but seeing as the eligibility would be determined by behaviour, it wouldn't surprise me if adults were more prevalent in this queue. 

What it comes down to is : are we splitting the player community too much by doing this? In the sense that queue's might take longer for both groups of people. It's a really tough point to discuss, Because at some point we might find ourselves looking at a worst case scenario, that being : A clear majority of the community could find themselves playing in this new queue, leaving the others having to wait a lot longer to get their matches made.
This point brings into question : how would eligibility work exactly? are we talking about temporary bans from this queue for toxicity? what time periods, weeks? months? Could this be abused by people?

These are some points.. But then you have to consider:
How effective will the reporting system be at the time? How would it work? 
One Idea that I have that may be effective (you can tell me if this has any flaws to it) is having a sort of AbuseBuster system implemented into the game. It could be a chat filter that recognises certain expressions. There are a number of words that aren't exactly necessary in social environments, i'm sure you could think of a few - words that we take for granted in most cases, even if not in an abusive context. Alienating these words from the game can do a lot for our community.

Sure it's a limitation on our freedom of expression, if you don't like what someones saying - mute them?
But that's another problem of it's own. To mute someone in your team, you are putting yourself at a disadvantage, solely for the reason that this person could have potentially been someone who was valuable to the team. So I don't think muting is a complete solution to combatting abuse in league. Having said that, I don't really see much of an alternative to *dealing with abuse*.
I think it would be unfair to the community to be told that they cannot speak in a certain way, which is why it would be important to have this alternative queue rather than AbuseBuster being implemented into the only platform for ranked.

This is because, If league were to alienate abusive behaviour *completely* they might end up losing a fair few numbers on their player base.
Some people can't change, but for those that can, let's allow them something a little better to strive for.
nah people will just lie about their age anyway
We already heard this same thing a week ago. Age does not mean you're mature or immature. Stereotypes just %%%% everyone over.

Appreciate the response as it allows more discussion on the issue.
Stereotypes are a tricky thing, but we learn a lot from them.
I think that simply abiding by "age" doesn't necessarily achieve what I'm trying to suggest.
I think that it's more to do with behaviour, which generally tends to evolve over certain age-groups that is responsible for how the community is at the time being. Adults have a tendency to know better, this is an indisputable fact. Sure, there are some of us who lack proper-behaviour, but that doesn't necessarily contradict the point aforementioned. Children are more prone to act erratically,  and that has a lot to do with their yet-developing social awareness. This isn't to say that some children don't mature early, but when you look at a majority, it's a fact that seems to be significant in pointing out.
